name: Tyrus
subtitle: Boost & Envelope Wavefolder
features:
Analog Boost + Envelope-Driven Wavefolder
A dynamic front end feeds a responsive wavefolding stage, letting harmonics emerge according to touch rather than force alone.

Dynamic, Not Compressed
Playing nuance is preserved. Each note unfolds differently depending on attack, sustain, and intent.

Wide Harmonic Vocabulary
Moves fluidly from radiant edge and vocal saturation to metallic tension and carefully managed chaos.

Symmetry and Fracture
Clean and folded signals coexist—stillness and pressure meeting at the fold point, usually without arguing.
desc: Tyrus is an expressive wavefolding instrument shaped by touch, force, and balance. Guided by Apollo and the sacred swans said to carry his voice, it explores that precise moment when harmony is gently persuaded into transformation. This is not a conventional distortion pedal, nor is it interested in pretending to be one. At its core, Tyrus pairs an always-on analog boost with an envelope-driven wavefolder, allowing sound to respond naturally to how it's played. Play lightly and the tone remains open and articulate. Dig in and the waveform bends, blooms, and fractures; revealing harmonics that feel reactive, vocal, and very much alive. Tyrus doesn't compress your playing into obedience; it listens, then responds.

name: Eclipse
subtitle: Dual Filter
features:
Parallel Dual-Filter Architecture
Two resonant filters operate side by side, allowing frequencies to interact, overlap, and part ways with dignity.

Complex LFO Modulation
Drives evolving motion across the filter paths, producing organic sweeps, rhythmic pulses, and slow, hypnotic shifts.

Stereo Image Control
Creates width, movement, and spatial depth, making sound feel larger, closer, or slightly off to one side.

Precision Frequency Sculpting
Capable of both surgical tone shaping and immersive modulation, depending on how deliberately you approach it.
desc:
Eclipse is an instrument concerned with light, shadow, and what happens when both decide to occupy the same space. Guided by Apollo during one of his more contemplative moments, Eclipse explores the boundary where clarity gives way to motion, and motion becomes something quietly hypnotic. This is not a single filter doing a single job. Eclipse prefers to work in pairs.

At its core, Eclipse runs two resonant filters in parallel, allowing frequencies to be shaped, divided, and recombined while a complex LFO gently encourages them to move. Used with restraint, it delivers precise frequency sculpting and subtle spatial movement. Used with less restraint, it produces dark, swirling modulation that suggests depth, orbit, and the slow mechanics of celestial events. Designed for guitar, bass, synth, and modular systems, Eclipse integrates naturally into rigs that appreciate nuance, patience, and the occasional moment of controlled obscurity.

Nothing disappears entirely. It just moves.

name: Aeon
subtitle: Delay & Octave
features:
Bucket-Brigade Delay Engine
Delivers warm, organic repeats with the gentle degradation expected of analog timekeeping.

Sub-Octave Generator
Adds a clean, stable octave below the signal or its repeats, introducing depth, weight, and the sense that something large is moving underneath.

Infinite Oscillation
Allows repeats to feed back indefinitely, creating evolving textures, drones, and moments of reflection that may last longer than anticipated.

Trails Mode
Lets echoes continue naturally after bypass, because abruptly stopping time rarely ends well.
desc:
Aeon is an instrument concerned with time, depth, and the uncomfortable realization that both are more flexible than advertised. Guided by Apollo in his role as keeper of rhythm and order (and occasional breaker of both), Aeon explores what happens when echoes are allowed to linger, multiply, and drop an octave for emphasis.

At its core, Aeon pairs a classic bucket-brigade delay with a pristine sub-octave generator, allowing repeats to sink lower and stretch further with each pass. Used sparingly, it delivers warm, dimensional delay with added weight and gravity. Used less sparingly, it begins to suggest that time may not be linear after all. Trails drift, notes fold back on themselves, and the octave below quietly insists on being heard. Designed for guitar, bass, synth, and modular systems, Aeon integrates naturally into rigs that value atmosphere, patience, and the courage to let a sound finish its sentence.

Infinite oscillation is available for those moments when restraint feels optional.

name: Maelstrom
subtitle: Total Noise Generator
features:
Tri-Engine Gain Architecture
DS-1–inspired distortion, Big Muff–style fuzz, and TS-9–influenced overdrive coexist in a single system, each contributing its own opinion about how sound should be treated.

Feedback Control
Routes your signal back into itself, allowing pitch, harmonics, and intensity to evolve dynamically. Small adjustments can produce large results.

Controlled Instability
Capable of tight, aggressive tones or expansive, self-interacting noise fields, depending largely on how much you encourage it.

Designed for Play, Not Safety
Rewards curiosity, attention, and a willingness to listen carefully before turning the next knob.
desc:
Maelstrom is an instrument of chaos, thoughtfully arranged. Guided by Apollo in one of his less orderly moods, it explores what happens when a signal is encouraged—repeatedly and with enthusiasm—to argue with itself. This is not a polite pedal, and it makes no promises about behaving sensibly once you invite it into the signal chain.

At its heart, Maelstrom feeds your sound back through a network of pitch-shifting and gain stages, allowing distortion, fuzz, and overdrive to collide in ways that are sometimes musical and occasionally enlightening. Set carefully, it delivers controlled aggression and layered harmonic density. Push further and it begins to form its own ideas about structure, rhythm, and volume. Designed for guitar, bass, synth, and modular systems alike, Maelstrom integrates naturally into rigs that value exploration, restraint, and the occasional moment of brave decision-making.
 Warning: output levels may reach values best described as 'commited'

name: Pyr
subtitle: Expressive Distortion
features:
3-Stage MOSFET Fuzz Gain Block
Delivers a wide dynamic range, from controlled overdrive through fractured distortion to unstable fuzz, depending largely on how firmly you insist.

Precision Tone Shaping
A 1 dB high-pass filter refines low-end focus without stripping weight, preserving articulation and preventing unnecessary rumbling.

Buffered Output
Ensures consistent signal integrity across complex rigs, with smooth output control and no surprises of the electrical kind.

Expressive by Design
Maintains clarity at lower settings; introduces harmonic collision, octave artifacts, and mild unruliness when pushed.
desc:
Pyr is an expressive distortion instrument shaped by internal tension and release. Guided by Apollo—god of light, music, and inconvenient truths—it explores the narrow boundary where control, clarity, and intensity briefly agree to coexist. This is not a traditional fuzz pedal, and it would prefer not to be mistaken for one.

Pyr moves fluidly between articulate overdrive, fractured distortion, and unstable fuzz, responding directly to playing dynamics, signal level, and intent. Play gently and it behaves with admirable restraint. Push harder and it begins to reveal its more complicated opinions about harmony. Designed for guitar, bass, synth, modular, and CV-driven systems, Pyr integrates naturally into modern pedalboards and more ambitious signal paths alike.
